title: G2 (mathematics)
text:
In <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a>, G2 is the name of three simple <a href="Lie%20group">Lie group</a>s (a complex form, a compact real form and a split real form), their <a href="Lie%20algebra">Lie algebra</a>s formula_1 as well as some <a href="algebraic%20group">algebraic group</a>s. They are the smallest of the five exceptional <a href="simple%20Lie%20group">simple Lie group</a>s. G2 has rank 2 and dimension 14. It has two <a href="fundamental%20representation">fundamental representation</a>s, with dimension 7 and 14.
The compact form of G2 can be described as the <a href="automorphism%20group">automorphism group</a> of the <a href="Octonion">octonion algebra</a> or, equivalently, as the subgroup of SO(7) that preserves any chosen particular vector in its 8-dimensional <a href="Real%20representation">real</a> <a href="spinor">spinor</a> <a href="Group%20representation">representation</a> (a <a href="spin%20representation">spin representation</a>).
History.
The Lie algebra formula_2, being the smallest exceptional simple Lie algebra, was the first of these to be discovered in the attempt to classify simple Lie algebras. On May 23, 1887, <a href="Wilhelm%20Killing">Wilhelm Killing</a> wrote a letter to <a href="Friedrich%20Engel%20%28mathematician%29">Friedrich Engel</a> saying that he had found a 14-dimensional simple Lie algebra, which we now call formula_2.
In 1893, <a href="%C3%89lie%20Cartan">Élie Cartan</a> published a note describing an open set in formula_4 equipped with a 2-dimensional <a href="distribution%20%28differential%20geometry%29">distribution</a>—that is, a smoothly varying field of 2-dimensional subspaces of the tangent space—for which the Lie algebra formula_2 appears as the infinitesimal symmetries. In the same year, in the same journal, Engel noticed the same thing. Later it was discovered that the 2-dimensional distribution is closely related to a ball rolling on another ball. The space of configurations of the rolling ball is 5-dimensional, with a 2-dimensional distribution that describes motions of the ball where it rolls without slipping or twisting.
In 1900, Engel discovered that a generic antisymmetric trilinear form (or 3-form) on a 7-dimensional complex vector space is preserved by a group isomorphic to the complex form of G2.
In 1908 Cartan mentioned that the automorphism group of the octonions is a 14-dimensional simple Lie group. In 1914 he stated that this is the compact real form of G2.
In older books and papers, G2 is sometimes denoted by E2.

Weyl/Coxeter group.
Its <a href="Weyl%20group">Weyl</a>/<a href="Coxeter%20group">Coxeter</a> group formula_7 is the <a href="dihedral%20group">dihedral group</a> formula_8 of <a href="Coxeter%20group%23Properties">order</a> 12. It has minimal faithful degree formula_9.
Special holonomy.
G2 is one of the possible special groups that can appear as the <a href="holonomy">holonomy</a> group of a <a href="Riemannian%20metric">Riemannian metric</a>. The <a href="manifold">manifold</a>s of G2 holonomy are also called <a href="G2%20manifold">G2-manifolds</a>.

The 14-dimensional representation is the <a href="Adjoint%20representation%20of%20a%20Lie%20algebra">adjoint representation</a>, and the 7-dimensional one is action of G2 on the imaginary octonions.
There are two non-isomorphic irreducible representations of dimensions 77, 2079, 4928, 30107, etc. The <a href="fundamental%20representation">fundamental representation</a>s are those with dimensions 14 and 7 (corresponding to the two nodes in the <a href="%23Dynkin%20diagram">Dynkin diagram</a> in the order such that the triple arrow points from the first to the second).

Finite groups.
The group G2("q") is the points of the algebraic group G2 over the <a href="finite%20field">finite field</a> F"q".
